reviewText:
The movie looked very pretty at times, and was entertaining enough not to be boring.  But what I really want from science fiction, this movie delivered: it was thought-provoking.

Sure, there were some conceptual flaws.  Robots did not seem to need a power source, ever, and while they worked just fine underwater, a little spinach in their mouth could seriously hurt them.  And global warming supposedly raised sea levels far beyond anything plausible.

The one thing the movie does very well was what it was apparently trying to do, it makes us care deeply and emotionally about a single robot.  I suppose its similar to the way Spielberg's E.T. made many people care about aliens for the first time.

For me, this is also what was most thought-provoking, and saddening. You see, the movie portrays people as very morally shallow.  A stadium of people gleefully massacre robots, robots who could not do what they did without having complex internal lives, great knowledge, a will to live, and at least some rudimentary understanding of and use of emotions.  And yet that same audience is horrified at the prospect of killing something that looks like a boy crying.  This boy robot is will murder another similar robot, and almost kills a human boy, But all that really matters, to the people on screen and I suspect most of the audience in the theatre, is that this one robot knows how to pout and cry like a little human boy. The essence of moral worth is the feeling of strong emotions.

During most of the movie it looks like it is going to be a tragedy of human hubris gone terribly wrong.  But at the end we find a more positive scenario.  But then they invoke some silly mysticism to shy away from the natural really positive scenario. It should have been easy to create a robot mother who loves him as much as he loves her, and let them both live forever. Instead, they create a mother that can only last a day, at which point they both die.  What a crying shame.
Great potential and decent start disintegrates into psuedo-intellectual drivel. Great performances by Osment, Law, and Teddy, not enough to save movie. A sad attempt at a fairy tale.

I count myself among the many enthusiastic fans of this movie. I have since read hundreds and perhaps thousands of reviews now in attempt to understand why this film is so hits so strongly with some and misses so badly with others. There seems to be no personality type that distiguishes those who dig it from those who don't.  Entertainment Weekly offered some background on the story development that explain a little about why there might be this disparate reaction.  A.I. was a challenge to edit. When shooting was completed the film clocked in at four hours. David and Monica spend a lot more time bonding than what you see in the final film.  People who like the film seem to be able to readily infer the bond in the relationship without the additional exposition. The rest have difficulty making sense of this and feel the film abandons interesting opportunities for family dynamics. After more than ten years of discussion with Kubrick, Spielberg states it was important for him to stay focused on the four major set pieces that were the core of Kubricks vision for the film. The Switzer household, the Flesh Fair, Rouge City, and the frozen afterworld inhabited by advanced mechas. As described by the lead effects supervisor, Kubrick liked to establish environments and then abruptly pull people out of them. You see this most clearly in 2001: A Space Oddysey.  Kubrick wanted this method to be the storytelling method for A.I. as well.  People seeing the film find this a stimulating way to explore ideas. Others find it makes the story seem disjointed. You should view the film with the idea that it is going to be episodic rather than linear. It is more concerned with exploring ideas than maintaining a perfectly threaded storyline.  Mentally prepare yourself for this and you are less likely to become impatient looking for a quick wrap up in the last segment.  Jude Law prefered not to make any statement of his own opinion on the extensive cuts to some of his better scenes but stated he admired Steven Spielberg's choice to focus in on the David story. He eliminated whatever did not move that central story along.  As good of a film as I think it is, I don't see any point in going to a film you may hate.  I have some suggestions that may help decide if you are a good candidate to like or dislike A.I.People who passionately feel Spielberg is a hack over-rated director but are thinking of seeing this film anyway because of its strong Stanley Kubrick overtones seem the least likely to enjoy this film.  People who have been passionately awaiting this film for the last nine years also tend to be disappointed due to their personal expectations of what it would be like.
Fans of Spielberg films such as E.T., Saving Private Ryan and Schindler's List who appreciate his ablity to convey personal human moments that champion esteemable virtues like nobility and heroism will not find much to cuddle up to in this film. It more connects with the human experience of digging to find scraps of virtue in the rubble, rather than finding it on display. There are unrelieved moments of mental cruelty to David that one may wish were left unexplored. Humans in the film view the mecha as tools to perform a purpose. The film explores people who feel dehumanized by machines that have taken over their roles as lovers, workers and do things they used to do. There are none of the cute or warm moments that characterize many Spielberg films.  If you are intolerant of long films, you should probably stay away from A.I. While it is only two and a quarter hours, it has a measured pace and there are stretches without much dialog that are left open to observe the moment. Visually, there seems to be no real argument that A.I. is a treat for the eyes. And Haley Joel Osment and Jude Law turn in fascinating and commited performances. David's supertoy "Teddy" is sited as the best character in the movie. This is intended as either a compliment or a veiled insult depending on who is reviewing the film. There is no way to know who will like or dislike this film. My wish is that you would see A.I. and enjoy it. Those who still decide to go after reading my suggestions and other comments,understanding the history and structure of the film will, I hope, have a better chance of appreciating it. Something in your personality will ultimately determine if you leap easily over the hurdles that blocked others from really enjoying A.I. and come home with a great experience. However I also hope others knowing a few things about themselves and the film will steer clear of it and avoid a bad night out at the movies. Good luck.

I was able to see A.I. through a local free screening (not a member of the press).  I am usually not very impressed with most movies - they are predictable, labored and just plain stupid.
I saw the soft preview for the movie, with the ever-loving mother and son scenario.  Little did I know what I was in for.  I will not give anything away, but this movie will take you on quite a ride! You never knew what to expect next.  I went through the full range of emotions on this one.  I cried, I squirmed, I laughed, I was in awe!  The special effects are spectacular and seamless at the same time.  Some special effects are overdone and obvious - not here.  I would like to know how some of this was done!!
A.I. is both a tug of both light and dark.  I wasn't left with an overwhelming sense of one feeling or another, but this movie will have you thinking about it for days.  It makes you think about life itself, the future, your mere exsistence!  Okay, I'm getting too deep here...
While I was walking out of the theater, some people were obviously emotionally moved, while others felt drained, and disenchanted.  This movie has some very dark aspects that made me very uncomfortable, so I wouldn't recommend it to children under 10.  Spielberg said he would let his 9 yr. old son see it, but after explaining some things first.  I haven't been able to stop thinking about this movie, and can't wait to see it again.  There is so much that goes on, and so much detail, that it is a must second-see!  This is an incredible, complex intelligent film that I highly recommend.  The visuals are spectacular also.
Enough, enough!

Once again, I walk out of a Steven Spielberg film absolutely infuriated by his boundless arrogance.  The first two hours, as an independent unit, could probably make one of the finest films of the decade, drawing you in completely (with amazing effects) into a dark and dreamlike world full of both pain and bittersweet humor.  Jude Law and Haley Joel Osment are, of course, fabulous.  With the last half hour, though, it seems that the Kubrick muse abandons Spielberg.  His worst side takes over (the part of him that allowed him to create the "T-rex vs. San Diego" scene in "Lost World, Jurassic Park") resulting in an ending that compromises the integrity of the entire film and insults the viewer's intelligence.

From an outside point of view it's hard to tell where the problem lies but the end result of this film, one of infinite potential, ends up at best an interesting failure.  It is at turns overtly simple and sentimental, and at times attempts to be cold and sexy, but the Spielbergian "cute" obsessions run amok over Kubrick's and it all results in a mixed bag of a few goodies and a lot of mediocrity.
Overall, the film lacks in energy that only Jude Law's character provides - he is the dynamo that keeps it from rusting on its tracks.  The worst thing about the whole is that it's not really a bad film, but it continuously shows potential of being a great film - yet, unfailingly, at every interesting moment, suggesting either a transcendetal evolution of the storyline or a brooding insight into the characters and the futureworld they live in, it diverts back into its earlier meanderings and the result simply fails to excite.  Even the effects, fine as they are, are nothing all that special.
The preview I saw had people walking out in the middle of it, kids acting restless and 90% of the audience rushing out during the last scene.  I do recommend seeing it and making up your own mind, but please don't go in expecting heaven.  Maybe the Blue Fairy could fix it?

I saw this some years ago on HBO, without expectation, and flashed through it again here.
It is another feel-good gobbledy-gook pseudo-science thing which begins where it ends. It is an exercise in human vanity and nothing else. Looking at the script, it looks to me as if some of the writers were actually making fun of it or the audience.
Examples:
(*) "robots did not consume resources beyond their first manufacture" -- because we know machines like cars and appliances don't need energy.
(*)  "so essential an economic link in the chainmail of society" -- which is such a mixed metaphor (armored economies?) it means nothing at all.

So, the "boy" (played by a boy of course) wants to be a boy, just like all the horrible people he met on his journey. Where does that get you? Maybe he should want to be one of the aliens.
The script and plot was either written as a deliberate insult to its audience or was simply an amalgam of thoughtless edits by different people.
Anyway, it's all been done before, but the effects are pretty.

Joel Osment (who played David the AI synthbot) should have at least been nominated for an Oscar for this unique role and how well he did in it.
The movie is too long and was filmed and plotted in a confusing, slow, plodding way that sometimes resembled television rather than cinema, but it's worth watching just for the ethical and philosophical issues it raises regarding artificial intelligence, as well as the special effects and the vision of a dystopic, Idiocracy-type future.
As with a far better and more ominous movie on this topic, Ex Machina, we see that the AI synthbot/android industry hasn't learned the lessons of the book Frankenstein.
Creating artificial life forms that have simulated or actual consciousness, ego, and self-awareness is cruel, insane, and dangerous.
Check out the Sam Harris podcasts about AI. You will see that even those who want to profit from it warn that AI androids could overwhelm actual humans, as was shown in Ex Machina.
As with drones, GMOs, nuclear weapons, and other world-changing technology, this is one genie that should be left in the bottle.

Man should never play God. This is a perfect example of the human spirit put into a machine.  I like how it depicts the latent evil with in us, and how from children to adults we are all dark at our core. Even though one may not plan to be dark, life sometimes through circumstances brings out our true nature.
Without Christ all is lost, and life loses its meaning. I see many biblical parallels and idioms in Spielberg's film.  The movie was very intense and had a good sense of humor with the Gigolo hooker.
Lastly, was the execution of the AI's supposed to be a certain people's persecution for what they were? It was almost holocaust  like in that scene and the chasing and capturing of the AI.

The actual movie itself was not good. The story could have been great, but ended in the realm of unbelievable at the end. It seems like a last ditch effort to try to give our main character what he wanted, but was so outrageous it spoiled the movie. I wanted our main character to get what he wanted and complete his quest, but wow. I definitely would not recommend this movie to anyone. It does bring up a good concept of "when do we cross that line" and "should we", but it could have been delivered so much better. The acting itself was okay. At the end, my wife was in tears, my mother was confused, emotional, and distraught, and I was disappointed and angry. None of us ever want to see this movie again.

This movie was just totally ridiculous. I'm not going to even bother spending 1/2 an hour explaining why, it's not worth that either. A robot has feelings, he ends up entombed in a machine, weird ridiculous looking robot aliens find him and he just happens to power up again after 2,000 years. That's just a small part of the ridiculousness. Take out the part about Gigolo Joe and you have a perfect stupid kiddie fairly tale. Or leave Gigolo Joe in there and have a stupid, ridiculous - sorry, hate to wear that word out but it's the only one that fits - fairy tale written for little kiddies that's too mature for them to watch, so this waste of time really has no purpose. And people got emotional over this? Seriously? Okay, some of the effects were good, I'll give it that. With stupid crap like this, what makes anyone think Spielberg is some kind of great writer? This was pathetic. Ridiculous!

Review of A.I. Artificial Intelligence
Hot Toasty Rag, December 8, 2017

I don't know who came up with the idea to make this movieokay, I do: Steven Spielberg and Stanley Kubrickbut if I could choose one movie that should never have been made, it just might be A.I. Artificial Intelligence. It is one of the saddest films Ive ever seen, and when my family went enthusiastically to see it in the theaters upon its release, we all ended up in a gigantic puddle of tears. Please, even if you live off of science fiction films, stay away from this one.

Haley Joel Osment, one of the most talented child actors in existence, stars as a robotic child. Set in a futuristic world in which several major cities have been swallowed up by the aftermaths of global warming, robots are now readily available and blend in pretty well with the rest of society. Frances OConnor and Sam Robards adopt Haley because their human son is on the brink of death. While he falls in love with his family, they don't feel the same way, especially when their real son recovers from his illness and rejoins the family. As a robot, Haley feels real emotions, but sometimes doesnt understand the reason behind them. In one scene, he overhears Sam telling Frances she smells good, so Haley drenches himself in an entire bottle of her perfume in order to gain Sams love. In another, hes sitting at the table during dinnerwhich he cant partake of because hes a robotand he tries to eat so he doesnt feel so isolated from the family. Those are only two of countless heartbreaking scenes in the film.

I cant imagine any mother making it through this movie in one piece, and if you were thinking of letting your children watch it, think again. Frances ends up dropping Haley off in the middle of the woods and abandoning him with nothing but his mechanical teddy bear for comfort. Even now, sixteen years later, that scene is vivid in my mind, and I wish as fervently as I did then that Id never seen this movie.

There is only one good element in the movie: Jude Law. He plays a male prostitute robot, and his performance is excellent. Haley Joel Osment is wonderful as well, and its mind-boggling to see such talent at a young age, but its also frustrating to watchhis parents allowed him to act in such an upsetting film, and that takes some of the joy out of watching his talent. But back to Jude Law: if youve never seen him before, you might think that he wasn't a real actor. Hes so convincing in his movements, expressions, and delivery that it seems like hes a computer-generated character. If the movie wasn't so horrendously disturbing, it might be worth watching for his performance.

Kiddy warning: Obviously, you have control over your own children. However, due to extremely upsetting scenes involving children, I wouldnt let my kids watch it.
great movie to show kids and every ai love it

Great visuals and really good acting but the real surprise is how Spielberg went beyond his usual, family friendly model of film making (undoubtedly influenced by Kubrick's initial involvement) to create a dark, often grim tale of what makes one a "human" with the real question being can real human emotion and intelligence ever be "artificial"? There is a clear distinction given between logical "data processing" which clearly can be effectively accomplished by "mechos" or machines and intelligent interaction involving feelings that puts ones capable of it beyond "artificial". Several scenes in the movie drives home this point - Law's gigolo character connecting emotionally with a human client as only a "human" can, crowd at the "mecho" destruction show turning against the human ring leader to save the boy (Osmond character) knowing full well he's a machine. So the question is why are they so willing to pay to see the destruction of other machos in all the gory, imaginative ways and yet not willing to see the boy destroyed? It's because emotion is a key component of human intelligence and that's what separates cold, logical data processing of "artificial intelligence" of robots from humans. Once emotional thinking becomes part of ones thought process, that being is no longer "artificial" no matter what the physical makeup is, that being is on an equal footing with "humans". The aliens who uncover the frozen boy at the conclusion of the movie fully understand this concept as they grant the boy the wish of being "real" without hesitation nor regard for the fact that he's not flesh and blood.

Begun by the legendary and often demanding Stanley Kubrick and finished by the equally legendary Steven Spielberg, AI Artificial Intelligence is a futuristic retelling of the classic 1881 Florentine Italian tale Pinocchio by Carlo Collodi.  Of course most modern children and adults are only familiar with the Disney animated rendition which can be considered a Readers Digest Condensed version of the original story.  Kubrick is often demanding in that if he can't make it happen and appear the way he wants it, he will abandon an idea or even an entire project.  For instance, since he could not use the available technology at the time, to recreate Stephen King's topiaries come to life in The Shining, he abandoned the idea to a daunting maze.  Similarly, he felt he did not have the creative team necessary to replicate a robot boy so real that it is nearly human, not without using a human child actor, but because of ET and Jurassic Park, he did feel his friend Spielberg was up to the task.  The ambitious result is one of the best science fiction films ever made, one which I believe stands shoulders to Kubrick's 2001 A Space Odyssey.

AI is possibly the best telling or retelling of Pinocchio there is, at the very least capturing the adventure, the emotion, and the spirit of the classic story.  This movie and The 6th Sense are definitively Haley Joel Osment's best works by far.  Both movies required a humanly emotive and caring child who could very subtly cast a spooky unnatural edge to the character.  Haley Joel brings it in by the truckload.  Perfectly cast, he was Spielberg's most brilliant decision in the film.  This is a story about Love, pure and simple, a three hanky movie in more than a couple places, but wildly adventurous, often edge of the seat thrilling, and humorous as well.  And then there are the stunning sequences of astonishing Kubrickesque visual sequences which I will not divulge since Lord-Willing there might be someone out there who has not enjoyed this fantastic film and I HATE spoilers.

There are plenty of existential as well as scientific and emotional discourses to ponder through the story and consider afterwards, you will undoubtedly return to it a few times if not more.  It is of the caliber of those science fiction films which elicit thoughtful point-counterpoint discussions after viewing; films like 2001 already mentioned, the recent Interstellar and Arrival as well. AI fits into the sub-genre of "intelligent science fiction", stimulating and idea provoking.  It considers several philosophical arguments as well.  Can a computer program love?  When does mechanical become life?  And so much more?  Lastly, is there really a Blue Fairy?

This is one of the Great Science Fiction films, nearly perfect, especially if the viewer is human and has feelings.  Enjoy this film.  Make a special effort to note the subtle differences (very calculated by both Stanley and Steven) between Mommy and Daddy, Human Children and David (Haley Joel); between Haley Joel and other mechas like Gigolo Joe (Jude Law) and other even more primitive mechas; compare Dr. Hobby to Geppetto in the original story, and finally ask yourself which character really does know how to love.
This is a great movie.  A wonderful Pinocchio retelling.  I teach the short story in my Sci-Fi unit, and then show this to my students.  They absolutely love this story.

Artificial Intelligence, a movie directed by Steven Spielberg, is a classic tale of courage and determination, told with a futuristic backdrop.  The story begins with David, a mecha robot boy, whose sole design is to fulfill the emptiness of parents who have lost or cannot have children.  On the outside, David looks like a normal kid, but on the inside David has been artificially engineered by Professor Hobby, the lead researcher at the company Cybertronics.

Monica and Henry become the lucky parents who agree to give David a test drive, believing David can relieve the family of a hole left by their terminally ill son, Martin, who is locked in a cryogenic chamber.

But after a series of close-calls that unsettle the family, Davids mother decides to abandon David in the forest.  Emotionally distraught, David begins a long journey to find the elusive, Blue Fairy who, in the famous story of Pinocchio, turns Pinocchio into a real boy.  Davids determination is what makes the second half of the film so poignant.  That despite constant setbacks along the way, David earnestly seeks to find the blue fairy so that she will turn him into a real boy. Thus, he will reach his ultimate goal: his mothers unconditional love.

Davids struggle throughout the film reflects what most people, regardless of age, seek to find in life--namely, authenticity, individuality, and love.  By the movies near-end, David finally finds a model of a blue fairy, and for remarkably 2,000 years, he continually asks the same question, Will you make me a real boy? Davids energy makes us analyze our own dreams and wishes, enlarging our understanding of what it means to sacrifice ourselves for the ones we love.

After humans are long gone and ice has frozen over, it is 2,000 later, and David is found by aliens at the site of the blue fairy model.  The aliens download all of Davids memories and then construct for David a final scene in the classic Spielbergian sense, showing the mother-son bond in its pure form; the scene is a happy montage of connection and love, a day David has hoped for his entire life.  However, the scene is haunted by the reality that this will be the very last time David ever gets with his mother.  Of course, Davids untameable optimism goes unchecked, as he responds to the alien, Maybe this time it will be different and she will stay with me forever.

Artificial Intelligence strives to answer age old questions: What responsibilities do we have to our makers?  Is love an unconditional force?  How can we distinguish between real and artificial love?  Are humans the only ones capable of genuine love?  Can a robot love more than a human being?  And if so, would that still be considered love?

True, this is a movie that raises more questions than it does answers about the future of our species and our unique relationship with technology.  But ultimately this story is a story of us--of our longings, frailties, hopes and dreams--all told through the eyes of a robot.  Artificial Intelligence accomplishes a great deal in the hour and half it runs, but most notably it exemplifies the enduring power of love, no matter if it is programmed mechanically or organically.

I purchased this DVD (2-discs) A.I. Artificial Intelligence many years ago.  I had seen this fantastic Steven Spielberg film with Haley Joel Osment and Jude Law at the movies and loved it so much that I purchased the DVD.  Sadly, there has been a lot of mixed reviews of this DVD, which I personally think it strange.  This film is a thinking persons movie and deals with a subject in which must be addressed in the future concerning robots. If the main requirement of being considered human is "self- awareness" than we must confront the fact that robots indeed may someday soon develop awareness.

This movie is also is an emotional film and when David (Joel Osment) is abandoned after being programed to love his human mother it is truly a sad scene. Jude Law is also great in his role as Mecha who befriends David.  This movie is a masterpiece as far as I am concerned.  This film moves along at a fast pace as David searches for his own true identity and purpose.  If you are into dark but yet beautiful movies at the same time you should check out this DVD.  You will either love or hate this movie depending on your personal view and philosophy about the future of technology  and human responsibility.

As with any good sci-fi story, there is an excellent underlying moral  and warning.  No matter how many times the "sci-fi Gods" try to warn us against "playing GOD", this movie is yet another telling of the story of "unintended consequences" when our human need to get a "undo/do-over" on outcomes that actually require mourning, letting go and moving on.  So, as the story goes, as soon as the tech is available we humans are gonna make "people in our own image" and "woe be unto them and us"  But, we will do it anyway, because, "we can" and despite all warnings.  Then we will freak out because as it turns out we are not as good as playing GOD as our meager tech and inflated egos would let us believe. Yay, being HUMAN in WESTWORLD- btw- two excellent sci-fi series with a reminder that once chaos theory takes over, there is just "no putting those genies back"Answers the age old question, "is it intelligent for humans to make artificial beings?" I somehow never knew about A.I Artificial Intelligence until last night.  It's surprising given the movie was released around the time Haley Joel Osment was really popular.

Haley Joel Osment plays the role of a robotic boy called a mecha child created by cybertronics who is soon adopted into the home of a husband (Sam Robards) his wife Frances O'Connor, and their son Jake Thomas.  Haley is so realistic he looks, acts and talk like an actual young boy!  That's the problem with movies that try to make people look like robots- it's impossible when it comes to several movements such as standing up and sitting down where you can instantly tell they're human.  You can't really pretend you're a robot in these situations.  Not really a complaint though.

Turns out there's certain things Haley can't do.  He can't eat food or he'll malfunction.  Did you see the way his eyes were dripping after gulping down spinach?  Ewww (and that's just for eating spinach!) but apparently he can lay on the bottom of a swimming pool surrounded by water for long periods of time without a problem.  Huh?  Wouldn't he rust or short out?

Anyway Jake is basically jealous of Haley because Haley's the one getting all the attention by the parents, so the two often conflict.  While in Jake's bedroom they often have many discussions about how Jake's real whereas Haley's not.  Jake often mocks and encourages Haley to do bad things, and even though Haley's programmed to disagree, Jake finds a way to talk him into it (such as cutting Frances hair while she's sleeping).  Who knows why Haley thought it would be a good idea to grab Jake and toss him into the bottom of a swimming pool.  Pretty sure Haley picked the wrong boy!

Knowing that the family is getting too attached to a robot, Frances thinks about driving Haley to the robot factory to return him only to change her mind at the last second and drop him off into the woods.  This is because she fears they'll tear his bolts apart I guess.  Really emotional stuff happening here- Frances crying as she explains why she must leave him, and crying harder as Haley tries to understand Frances decision.  He's too human darn it!  *grabs tissues*

This is the first half of the movie.  The second half is all about Haley going off on his own discovering where he belongs in a world with robots roaming around with humans.  Because Haley has human-like emotions he feels trapped between the human and robot world.  Neither one welcomes him it would seem.  You know this is unrelated but his character reminds me of the Mega Man video game series.  Isn't Mega Man a robot boy?  Yup, just like Haley!

I think the movie was a lot better and less confusing in the first half while the story played it low key around the home with Frances family.  The focus in the first half is mainly about Frances and how she deals with her emotions and attachments to Haley.  Without spoilng anything major, the second half of the movie abandons the family stuff completely as Haley embarks on his own through the woods and city streets.  Heavy emphasis on science fiction during this one scene where the robots are trying to find workable parts they can attach to their bodies at a dump site.  Sort of creepy too!

I find the movie less interesting and Matrix-like when Jude Law enters the scene since his presence is beyond bizarre and introduced awkwardly (I was like "What the heck is going on?" when he first appeared).  The story gets confusing when time travel comes into the writing, or rather, when the story jumps ahead thousands of years due to certain events later on I won't spoil.

The woman (called the Blue Fairy) who appears in the other room and whispers "Daaaaaaavid" and moves around like a robot creeped me out like you wouldn't believe.  Her voice and movements felt like some kind of realistic dream!  It made the hair on the back of my arms stand up!  Also Teddy, a teddy bear that Haley has as a companion, moves around a little too real for my liking.  Not that I ever saw a teddy bear walk and talk like a person but I imagine it would look like the one in this movie!  The scene where the bear is running through the woods is unforgettable.

You can do a google search to find out other people's opinions about the ending, and it's actually fascinating reading other people's views because it reveals the story and writing is actually WAY more complex than I ever could have imagined.  Without spoiling the ending let's just say... reunited and it feels so good... or does it?  I like the way people analyze Haley's emotions.  Yeah he does strike me as obsessive and desperately wanting love.  Though I haven't mentioned it yet, Haley was the perfect choice for actor too.

So yeah, really good movie with an ending that some might consider sad, others happy, others satisfied.  Or maybe the opposite.  I don't know how you'll feel about the ending.  I liked it, and after reading reviews for the movie online I realized this movie's more awesome than I initially thought.

I was just passing through movies and not interested in the title but the scene I saw first (probably 10-15 minutes into the film) was the wonderful face and eyes of Osment. The boy captures your soul with his look of longing! Where could they take a robot boy given to a couple whose son soon returned from a coma and replaced the robot boy? The answer was Pinocchio and how he became a real boy. But even toward the end of this enthralling tale when you think it's about over, suddenly every child's wish is fulfilled in the final lines from his real life mother for the one day she is permitted to return to life. "David, I love you and I've always loved you." This is the answer to every child's question, "Do you really love ME and am I REALLY different?" I couldn't believe I cried but I did because it answered everybody's question about themselves. Should children see this movie. No, no, no! This movie is for adults and for parents. Children are not likely to understand or enjoy this dark human condition of no love for a child.

A Futuristic Tale ??
The Ice-Caps have melted many major cities have disappeared below the advancing Seas, those who have survived
have moved to the interiors of their continent, resources are limited
It is the age of Robots, what if they could be created to love, and assigned to family's as an addition instead of having
more children to stretch to stretch the already limited supply of food the great floods had caused.
'Henry' (Sam Robards) and wife 'Monica' (Frances O'Connor) have a child who is in a coma and unlikely to recover, they
are chosen to have a real-looking and loving Robot-Boy 'David' (Haley Joel Osment) who will love without question.
'Monica' struggles to accept young 'David' but will try, however things are about to change when real-son 'Martin' unexpectedly
shows signs of recover when a cure for his condition is foundand is allowed home.
'Martin' is encouraged to interact with 'David' but his human-instincts reject a meaningful relationship with his Robot bother.
When 'Martin' with friends taunt 'David' things go very wrong so much so 'Monica' decides to take little 'David' to the forest
and abandon him despite his pleas not to be left alone with just 'Teddy' for company......all 'David' ever wanted from his adopted
parents was the love he'd been programmed to give them.
'David' finds himself in a World in which 'Robots' are used as fairground fodder to be publicly destroyed it is under those circumstances he meets and teams up with 'Gigolo Joe' (Jude Law) who he escapes with whom he begins an adventure.
Whatever is yet to come for 'David' one constant will remain with him forever - his love for his human mother 'Monica'
...all he'll ever want is for her to love him back.
A charming and delightful if perhaps a little sad tale from 'Steven Speilberg' .
Young 'Haley Joel Osment' magnificent in the role of the Artificial Intelligence who only ever wanted to be loved

I can't write a full review of film here, but it was really good.  As fiction, it is a unique take on the promethean myth, and our responsibility as humans when it comes to the increasing use of the digital and virtual to fill our needs.  This film was made in 2001, which is interesting considering that was the when internet and personal computing devices were becoming far more popular.  It's really a relevant subject today.  I do not believe that robots will live on beyond humans.  We are more eternal in nature than robots, but the film also explores how an artificial intelligence cannot attain "realness" or life in the same way as a human.  It brings up questions of the soul and of afterlife.

The film has some content that might not be suitable for children as far as robots that are designed for prostitution, etc.  But there is nothing explicit like graphic violence, sexual scenes, or hard profanity that would make most any adult uncomfortable or offended.

As this movie had plenty of potential to be a considerably awesome movie, it succeeds in some things, but outright fails in the long run.  Here's the major gist as to how that goes:

The movies positive points:

The visuals for the house that Monica, David, Henry, and Martin live in makes for beautiful scenery,  the usage of colorful neon lights for the futuristic cities and the villains the biker hounds motorcycles were breathtakingly beautiful, the robot teddy bear simply known as Teddy was a neat character, Jude Law proved to be likable, a loyal friend to David, charming, and made for some great comic relief as Gigolo Joe, the shots of a mostly flooded Manhattan along with the cool crying lions statues were a cool touch, the special effects were awesome,  the acting is good(especially, Haley Joel Osment's and Jude Law's performances) the initial acceptance that the Swinton's had for David was touching even if only temporary, the pacing is good at times, there are some attractive people in the cast, and David proves a character that the audience can feel for.

The Negatives:

Monica goes from great skepticism as to whether or not she can accept David as her son to accepting him especially to the point of pressing the button on the back of his head to receive unconditional love from him only to totally abandon him in the woods,  there's no explanation as to what happened to their human son Martin that caused him to become both comatose and frozen in a hyperbaric chamber, when Martin comes out of his coma, for no clear rhyme or reason somehow he functions normally with no confusion, no disorientation, no slurred speech, no faulty motor functions outside of his need for mechanical leg attachments, and no curiousity as to what has changed since he was literally out cold,  also Martin totally treats David like a bothersome thorn in his side which he shows by  trying to either get David into trouble or to try and get a rise out of him, Henry believing David to be capable of hate and a possible threat, Gigolo Joe getting captured by the police, that whole thing with the Flesh Fair, the fact that humans would be sick enough to watch robots being demolished to begin with, the fact that it was neither made clear as to whether or not the Flesh Fair was legal or by that token much less as to whether or not robots were actually considered to be official citizens or not, the feeling that you get that David may have been the only mecha child, David's incessant obsession to find a blue fairy like the one in PInocchio to hope to become human and be accepted by his human mother Monica got annoying after a while, the mention of the polar ice caps melting is not only an uninteresting plot point, but it doesn't play into the movie to any real degree, the concern over overpopulation brought about by limiting how many children a family can have was very little explained, it didn't make any sense, and to make matters worse it steals from the Christopher Lambert movie Fortress, parts of the movie's plot are clearly stolen from Bicentennial Man also.  Isn't so convenient how ideas from far superior sci-fi movies would be plagiarized?  This movie's uneven emotional tone(s) that bring about it constantly having happy tones to it and then going into some sadness or tragedy and doing this throughout the whole course of the movie. That direction to it was very aggravating.  David going psycho as he for no reason destroys another David robot, and the ending turning out to be more sad than actually happy to say nothing of the fact that the ending also leaves things hanging too much proved to be another major flaw in this movie.

In general, this movie just doesn't seem to know as to where it's going in terms of emotional tones.  It also has characters that are mean and nasty scumbags for no good reason.  Those characters being: Martin for his less than welcoming or loving brother behavior towards David, Monica for abandoning him when she could have tried to see to having him reprogrammed or tweaked in some way, all the people both running, working for and watching the Flesh Fair who want to do away with artificiality no matter how sick and callous that happens to be, Henry for thinking David a possible threat, and the killer allowing Gigolo Joe to be wrongfully accused of murder.  They are all unlikable scum that ruin this movie in part.  The way that this movie shamefully steals ideas from far better sci-fi films.  It was a shame that Teddy doesn't talk a lot more than he does.  The movie's pace is too inconsistent.  The movie's length proved an unnecessary near 2 1/2 hours.  Above all and I can't emphasize this enough, if you're expecting an ending that's conclusive or happy, well unfortunately that's not what you're going to get.  This movie is just too sad and full of tragedy to be particularly enjoyable.
Amazing performances/ Great story, a true tear jerker and beautiful screen resolution.  This not for kids thinking it will be like E.T.  Many complex sci/fi content.

This was a great movie.  It was novel for its time and with all the gruesome things I see and hear happening in real life today, some of the basic themes in this movie are not so far fetched.  We human beings can be a nasty little species.  I find it interesting that we can be capable of the loftiest feelings and actions but there is a segment of the general population that isn't that far removed from the cave.  Even so, some of the best of us can revert to that primal response under the right circumstances.  The attitude of the adoptive mother in this movie can be compared to unthinkable actions committed by women today in our own so-called "civilized" era.  All you have to do is turn on the news on TV.  The same basic premise of abandoning - in one way or another - a child whether human or artificial requires something that should be foreign to all human females.  Technology has progressed with lightning speed but the developing refinement of human emotion and higher morality seems to be lagging far behind.  In fact, some people may be regressing in that department.  We can criticize and be repelled by other cultures for their barbarism and acts of savagery but they have lacked progress and remained static for hundreds of years.  Based on our history, we Americans have no excuse for the excesses tolerated and often encouraged by society today.  Yes, there were slips and terrible acts committed along the way, but we as a nation have made tremendous progress to rectify those actions  and,  it is still a work in progress.  That is why it is so disheartening to see modern society become what it has - almost suicidal.  Thus, this movie's imaginings of what the future might hold I find totally plausible.

This is a dark, brilliant and in many ways beautiful film.  I found it frankly very frightening and horrifying a lot of the time, and the ending left me deeply sad and deeply anxious.  Some might call this a horror movie.  It's beautifully made, beautifully photographed, beautifully directed, acted, etc.  But I can't recommend this with my whole heart to anyone and everyone.  And I would be very cautious about ever exposing a child to this film.  This is a true work of art that many will not find at all entertaining.  And some, like me, will find nightmarish.  It reminded me of "Blade Runner," but I found "Blade Runner" a much more affirmative film.  This presents a bleak vision of the future, but a profound vision of human nature, exploring  the great human need for and the capacity to love.  It struck me as far too stark and uncompromising to ever be sentimental.  Whatever my reservations about the violent, horrifying elements,and the terrifying overview of this film,  I certainly see this as a magnificent creative achievement.

One of Spielberg's least successful films. He indulges entirely too much in his penchant for tearjerking mawkishness, especially in the first and unforgivably maudlin last acts. Everything's slow and and sad and weepy and heavy, but ultimately too silly to have anything like true gravitas or seriousness. The crucial role of the mom is so badly and vaguely written that Frances O'Connor just never gets a handle on her. But then, all the humans are robotlike empty shells, and it's two of the mechanicals -- Jude Law and the Teddy Bear -- who get all the best lines and moments. You get the sense Spielberg wanted to provoke thought but he's too busy jerking your chain. It's got some well-executed moments, some classic Spielberg moments, but they're desert islands in this sea of tears. It's a six-hanky weeper that's all heart and no head.

When Spielberg inherited the "A.I." project from Stanley Kubrick, he could have made the film exactly as Kubrick would have carried it out in style and function.  If he had done so, his critics would surely have accused him of mere mimicry and would probably have unfairly and unfavorably compared him to the older director.  Well, Spielberg did the film his way, and people still complained that if Kubrick had done it, it would have somehow been better.  Let's accept it:  This is Spielberg's film, no matter who wrote the story on which it's based and no matter how important the filmmaker who preceded him on the project.  We must credit Spielberg for having had the guts to undertake the venture at all, whether we think he succeeded in creating a masterpiece or not.

Frankly, I find it a little dismaying that so many critics and moviegoers disparaged the film.  No, it is not one of my favorite movies of all time, but I cannot deny the importance of the story, with its social, philosophical, and ethical themes.  This is a film that dares to tackle moral issues, while at the same time attempting to entertain.  And, for me, the thought-provoking elements of the story line are every bit as much a part of the entertainment factor as are the captivating sights of humanlike robots, futuristic hover crafts, and fantastically elaborate cities.  In "A.I.," Spielberg combines thought and vision, mind and heart, to create an entirely engaging movie.

About the time of the film's release, "PC Magazine" (Sept. 4, 2001) asked Dr. Brian Scassellati, who led the Cog robot project at MIT's Artificial Intelligence Lab, whether the movie's plot was plausible.  In answer to the question, "Will robots ever be able to feel love?"  Dr. Scassellati replied, "It depends on what you mean by 'feel.'  I think that we're clearly going to be able to build something that shows the outward characteristics--something that displays the correct emotions.  And then I think it's really a philosophical question of 'Does this thing really feel emotions?'  If we can show that outward appearance, that's basically the same thing.  It's the only way we understand people anyway; so in that way the robot has actually become a complete surrogate for another person."  Obviously, from this reply we can see that not even one of the top scientists in the field can define what it means truly to be alive, to feel, and to think.

"A.I." has the distinction of not only asking at what point artificial intelligence becomes "real" intelligence, but, in fact, what it means to be "real."  Or, haven't you noticed the robotic-like stances of all those people behind the counters in the mall, or the sterile, mechanical voices you hear so often in telephone solicitors.  In the film, David, the robotic child, is more "real," more responsive, more caring, than a few live people I've met over the years.

Of course, there is the metaphysical dilemma to address as well.  For countless centuries, religions have taught us that the difference between humans and lower animals is in the soul, the joining of a human body with a spiritual core.  It's the basis for most beliefs in an afterlife, that the spirit of the deceased ascends to another plane.  If Man can mechanically perfect the outward appearance of a human being and combine it with the capacity for self-motivated thought, would the resultant robot somehow acquire a spirit, a soul, as well?  Or, is that only in the province of God?  The film neatly and properly sidesteps the issue, neither Kubrick nor Spielberg willing to touch upon delicate religious convictions that might eclipse their own points.

A robot that can love is the aim of the future society in "A.I.," a child substitute with real subconscious love for its parents, not feigned, synthetic, programmed love.  Then, the film asks whether parents can love such a being in return.  However, the film never answers the question any more than Dr. Scassellati of MIT answered it.  Is this a shortcoming of the film, that it leaves the viewer with ambiguity at the end?  I think not.  To have provided facile answers to tough philosophic questions would have been purposeless and unjust to anyone but the viewer looking for absolute closure at any cost.  To leave it to audiences to decide for themselves the meaning of life, why we're here, and where we're going is far more imaginative and rewarding.

In more ways than one, "A.I." is like Kubrick's "2001," a film that posited similar queries.  Remember that in "A Space Odyssey" we see Man creating an artificial intelligence that can think for itself, albeit still in a programmed way, and then we see traces of a super-advanced galactic race guiding Mankind's destiny in much the same scheduled manner.  Are we any more or less programmed than HAL?  Perhaps only if we think of the question in the metaphysical sense.  John Williams's soft, otherworldly music accompanies most of the action in "A.I.," just as similar, though classical, music underlined the tensions in "2001."  Likewise, just as "2001" took us through time as well as space, much of the plot of "A.I." is broken into large and varying time periods, from the relatively near future to several millennia away.  Then, too, Spielberg makes allusions to his own "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," with our first image of David a blurred silhouette, appearing like one of the director's space aliens, an image repeated at the movie's end.

Despite its similarities to Kubrick's and Spielberg's own previous work, "A.I." is very much a late-Spielberg film.  It is sentimental and dewy-eyed, photographed largely in soft focus, something Kubrick would probably have avoided; yet the film moves along at a Kubrick pace, slowly and deliberately, delicately and leisurely, yet in a businesslike manner.  Furthermore, Spielberg emphasizes the psychological and ethical issues perhaps more openly than Kubrick might have done.  Spielberg probably overstates the whole business of the Pinocchio references, the Blue Fairy, and the question of whether robots can love or hate.  Does this make "A.I." a better or worse film than Kubrick might have envisioned?  Does it matter since it's Spielberg's film, after all?

In addition, I had some moderate concerns about Spielberg's emphasis on conspicuously showy effects and behavior.  For instance, would reasonably intelligent parents actually allow their million-dollar baby boy-toy, David, to get anywhere near the clutches of a group of real, live youngsters and not expect trouble?  Not if they know anything about human conduct they wouldn't.  Would the computer company that made David have allowed their model to practically destroy itself if it tried ingesting real food?  Probably not.  In the second half of the film, part of which corresponds to the island of pleasures in "Pinocchio," is it really necessary for the mechanical-hound motorcyclists to look so melodramatically fearsome, or is this mainly a cinematic device to keep the audience in their seats and not wander to the popcorn stand?  Indeed, is it necessary to change the tone so abruptly in the second half to one of flashy, tawdry seediness, with Gigolo Joe and the "Flesh Fair" so glaringly represented?  Yes, naturally, it's all a part of the myth, and it does point up the differences in the attitudes of people toward mechas, robots; but it also seems a tad too much an attention-getting device in a seriously thoughtful film.  Nevertheless, Spielberg does create some visually arresting scenes here of magnificent cities above and below the sea, and the spectacle absolutely keeps the pulse of the film alive, so I can't really complain.

Ultimately, I did find the movie becoming slightly tedious at over two-and-a-half hours, but I also found it well worth my time.  Perhaps the allegorical implications of the story didn't catch me as much as they did some people; perhaps I was too much aware of the director's attempts to be profound too much of the time.  I don't know.  I do know I liked the idea that if David had the self-motivation to chase down his dreams, he'd have been real enough for me not to want to hurt, mechanical being or no, with or without a soul.  If I would have qualms about hurting David, it must mean I would have feelings toward his feelings, a sure sign that something sensitive and moving was going on here.

Sure, the ending turns from the purely figurative and esoteric to the wholly emotional.  So what?  This isn't a doctoral treatise.  It's a film that shows its heart on its sleeve, a Spielberg characteristic, not a Kubrick one, but a trait with which I can easily live.

DreamWorks engineers use an MPEG-4/AVC codec and a dual-layer BD50 to transfer the picture to Blu-ray disc in its native aspect ratio, 1.85:1.  On one of the disc's featurettes, the filmmakers discuss the lighting used in the movie, which varies from soft, filtered shots to brightly lit, even gaudy scenes.  If you recall, Stanley Kubrick favored natural lighting whenever possible, so in deference to Kubrick's practices, Spielberg also uses natural and simulated natural lighting whenever he can.  He also uses a muted color pallette, oversaturated colors, high contrasts, low contrasts, backlighting, and other techniques that the viewer may or may not appreciate.

In any case, the picture quality of on BD looks good in capturing the director's intentions.  A fine film grain, inherent to the print, slightly veils the screen, along with a smoky look in the opening sequences.  The overall PQ is somewhat soft much of the time, but when Spielberg wants the image to look sharp, it does, indeed, look crisp and sharp; and the screen is quite clean, free of extraneous specks, lines, or scratches at all times.

Audio:
Using lossless DTS-HD Master Audio 6.1 for the soundtrack, the audio engineers capture the movie's subtle and not-so-subtle sounds effectively.  For the first third or more of the film, there is mainly dialogue, so don't expect a lot of activity in the surrounds at first.  Then, when the action of the escape and search scenes kicks in, you'll hear a variety of encircling noises from all the speakers, with strong bass, more than ample dynamic range and impact, and excellent clarity.  Even John Williams's musical score sounds good with its ambient bloom in the rear channels.

Extras:
DreamWorks carry over most of the extras from their two-disc DVD edition to the Blu-ray disc, most of the items in standard definition.  First up is "Creating A.I.," about twelve minutes of introduction with Spielberg and others summarizing the film's origins.  Next is "Acting A.I.," with two segments, "Portrait of David," four minutes on Haley Joel Osment's character, and "Portrait of Gigolo Joe," five minutes on Jude Law's character.  After that is "Designing A.I.," again in two segments:  "A.I. from Drawing to Set," seven minutes, and "Dressing A.I.," five minutes.  Then, "Lighting A.I." spends about four minutes on the look of the film, from its sterile beginning to more brightly lit action and dimly lit drama sequences.

Moving on, the next items seem self-explanatory:  "A.I./FX," seven minutes; "The Robots of A.I.," thirteen minutes; "Special Visual Effects and Animation:  A.I.," with five segments totaling about twenty-three minutes; and "The Sound and Music of A.I.," two parts of six minutes each.  A brief, two-minute section, "Closing:  Steven Spielberg:  Our Responsibility to Artificial Intelligence," kind of brings things to a close.  Almost.  Because there are still the "A.I. Archives," which include "Storyboards," "Chris Baker's Portfolio," a "Production Design Portfolio," "ILM Concept Art," a "Portrait Gallery," and a "Steven Spielberg Behind-the-Scenes Gallery," photographs for the latter two segments by David James.

The extras conclude with a pair of theatrical trailers in high definition; thirty-two scene selections; bookmarks; English, French, and Spanish spoken languages; English, French, and Spanish subtitles; English captions for the hearing impaired.  The movie comes with a handsomely embossed slipcover enclosing one of those lightweight Eco-cases guaranteed to save the planet and almost protect your disc.

Parting Thoughts:
If you've never seen "A.I. Artificial Intelligence" before, you may not know entirely what to expect.  In many ways, it's a typical Spielberg film in that it's thoughtful, sentimental, and well paced for its material.  But that material is not exactly what Spielberg might have handled himself if he hadn't taken on the project after Kubrick's death.  Nor should one try to compare the film to what Kubrick might have done with it.  We're left with a long, expansive, always illuminating but never didactic look at life and love and what they mean to Mankind.  Good enough.

"Flawed masterpiece" is used far too loosely, after all this is a second rate film and cannot be considered a masterpiece in any sense of the word.

However, it does have all of those familiar Spielberg moments. It is well crafted - unlike Kubrick, who snapped up the rights in the 1970s, who was a self contained genius - Spielberg has a healthy collaborative approach accounting for his remarkably consistent artistic and commercial success over a generation of wide ranging films. But great moments and memorable scenes do not make a great film: the leaden hand of film by committee or group brain storm is too heavy in this production. The whole is less than the sum of the parts, though none of those parts is less than entertaining or thought provoking.

Aldiss was ("I am - I was" thankfully at the ripe age of 89 still with us!) a speculative sci fi writer. He is a futurist with an emphasis on sociology when sociology was popular as a subject and when different types of social organisation thrived (see the reversioning of history today when corporate monopoly capitalism writes the books!) and his ideas in the books which sparked Kubrick's interest are focussed mostly on the future role of technology on society and human relationships rather than any inward philosophical journey into the nature of reality, consciousness or intelligence.

I cam across his travelogue of Tito's Yugoslavia, "Stones and Cities", widely regarded then as an excellent example of a socialist system non-aligned with either the USSR or the West, so as a writer he had a journalistic serious impetus which is sometimes cloaked by, but always benefits his fiction. He further wrote in depth about the collapse of communism, or rather the beginning of change, in the 1980s.

Since Kubrick had already been down that road with A Clockwork Orange, he seems to have been looking for a story vehicle to do something different, and a modern fairy tale approach to the whole film was quickly established in the early discussions of a screenplay between author and director. Aldiss disagreed wanting to largely stick to a tech tale. Aldiss left the project. Kubrick did not say goodbye. The fact that Kubrick had failed to reconcile the absurdities of his own approach and did not make the film shows Aldiss was right.

Hence the rather confused mish mash resulting here. Spielberg probably did as much as anybody could while adding his own brand of sentimental cream topping to the end result.

The film in dwelling on the issues of what is life, what is consciousness, what is "real", what is human identity, starts from a fairly low moral level and proceeds to the final "non-submersible unit" of a flooded New York frozen over in a 2,000 year future ice age when non-human life forms have taken over and are busily excavating their past. Why would they? It does this through a series of increasingly implausible scenarios resembling an increasingly grotesque and gaudy pantomine. The usual tricks are all too obviously employed when plot and story line falters: Spielberg has always been good at 360 degree aerial scenes so it not a surprise when the cuddlesome trio hijack a police helicopter and zoom off into the blue yonder.

In Aldiss's book Monica's spouse (for want of a better word) is also the head of the synthetic "human" corporation which delivers "David" and is a thoroughly nasty piece of work. He is what he would proudly call himself today a "manager" (in management) but in Aldiss's day when the book was written better described as a cold blooded technocrat. He is the sort of man who would manage a medical service (take the NHS in the UK for example) and in the aftermath of a scandal involving unnecessary deaths and suffering skip off with his contractual golden handshake without a word of apology. He may be a banker. Very likely a woman too - a negligent social worker. Or police officer, or Grand Jury judge ...as Pinter says: "You know the type of man we are talking about."

He is an operator - but then the author is "operating" artistically, in a fine balancing act, working the trick of making David seem real but constantly reminding the reader David is simply a cleverly programmed machine - in the human sense of operating to get personal advantage. Indeed, every character in this film is based on the same personality flaw. It is all self seeking lacking the essentially generous ingredient in human existence. There is no love or human caring in this film at any level in any moment. The fundamental conditions are lacking or invalid. By the end of it I found myself thoroughly detesting David though not disturbed by him.

If this is disturbing, it is not because we are disturbed by the life like "David" or unflinching comfort programmed "Teddy" or the machine bashing circus it is purely because of the adolescent immaturity of the thinking behind the film. The eventual recreation of some of Aldiss's ideas into this melange, after a two decade period of procrastination and stagnation, owes more to a thousand TM sessions in Hollywood, or a thousand R&D conferences, or Apple events than a rigorous effort to explore and develop those ideas.

AI is not a fairy tale - it is not good enough - and the attempt to blur the edges between reality and fantasy, what is really human and what is simulation, what is self awareness and human consciousness, rather than machine operation, is actually childish and rather unintelligent. Fairy tales are full of meaningful archetypes that form the human subconscious individual and collective and which permeate our history - there are none here.

There is an unlimited universe of difference between Artifical Intelligence and Human Intelligence. Currently a full understanding of the human brain and how it functions is beyond science. Many parts of the brain are still not understood at all. The capacity of the brain to store and organise information is not understood and still cannot be replicated by any machine now or likely in the future. The nature of human consciousness is not understood.

I had to give my views after reading yet another silly statement that machines are likely to replace humans in the future by none other than Steven Hawkings based on his local experience of the advances in his predictive speech device which have enabled him to communicate more easily. With respects to a rather sick man I can only say that he needs to get out more.

There is a richness and creative seed in human beings and their relationships which can never be replaced by machines. Those who say otherwise actually have a limited and under nourished view of life in general or are tending that way.

There is no life or love in Spielberg's film or Kubrick''s adaptation of Aldiss's work (which is deeply ironic) and hence it is fairly meaningless if interesting passing entertainment.
This movie was too sad

Yes, it meet my expectations & then some. I have a copy in DVD format already and wanted to take advantage of my Blue ray players superior output. It, the movie, provides us with a unique insight to the challenges that await any real attempts to duplicate some of the more difficult aspects connected to being a human.
I thank I enjoyed this more as a child, but still appreciate the great work and fantastic quality.

The "12" viewing certificate does not mean that there is material not suitable for younger audience, but clearly has to do with the more adult-oriented overall theme of the film, and their understanding of it. The story of a young boy-robot programmed with emotion, as naive and simple as it may seem, is a most complex and demanding affair. Yet, it makes for a riveting tale of how the feeling of love is overpowering his robotic programming. Not coincidentally, just like Antoine de Saint-Exupery's "The little prince", "A.I." is also a universal piece of art, with the youngest, yet, most wise protagonist. "The little prince" taught us that the essential things in life are seen not with the eyes, but with the heart. "A.I.", respectively, tells us that children give us the truthful wisdom we seek. Few contemporary films are as powerful and touching as "A.I." is, Stanley Kubrick's choice to trust the project to Steven Spielberg turned out to be a wise one. This impressive blu-ray presentation is most satisfying with the massive audio and visual improvements (the much talked-about grain issue is finally put to rest), contributing to the movie's conceptual and executional excellence. Only letdown is the absence of any new extras, as the bonus material featured on here is the exact DVD content with nothing new added. Still, this is absolutely worth adding to anyone's collection. Incredibly inspired, immaculately executed, spectacularly entertaining, and with an ending that can be interpreted as both tragic and liberating, "A.I." is St. Spielberg and St. Kubrick's hidden masterpiece, a breathtaking contemporary fairytale, and a truly unforgettable film.

***** for the film
***** for this edition

Sandwiched between the praised but poisonous bloodbath of "Saving Private Ryan" and the radical future-noir thriller "Minority Report" (which, in truth, is a depressing affair indeed to sit through), the much-anticipated (at least by film champions) collaborative effort between visionaries Kubrick and Spielberg is a rather rushed affair in tone--and, actually, it's devastating to think of how the more intense, and more immediately "plot-heavy" darkness of "Minority Report" completely washed this better film effort out of the mind of the Spielberg-watching public. In fact, my feeling is that no one understood what "A. I." was supposed to do or supposed to be; the historians contemplated it, the public eventually dismissed it, and the filmmakers had other things to do (poor Kubrick died before he saw it fulfilled even). Yet, with the passage of time, the film will prove even more so to be a Spielberg masterwork. Maybe the public cannot accept films that even remotely criticize the onslaught of technological progress. Because it does not contain raw violence (as the blood-thirsty public got so much of in the exploitative "...Ryan") and because it carries a rather dim, melancholy tone about a world completely over-thrown by technology and its robotic counterparts, I have to confess that I am duly impressed how Spielberg could keep all of this together in his own head, while not going the route of the redundant (Gilliam's "Twelve Monkeys") or taking the path of the savage (Scott's "Blade Runner"). It may be true that this film does not contain the fun of the Indiana Jones pictures, nor the sentiment of the misguided "Schindler's List" (the "Flesh Fair" in the film is both ironically sad and destructively chaotic, Holocaust-metaphor or not; actually, it is a case of Spielberg returning to his Serling/"Twilight Zone" television style metaphorical roots, in which fantasy themes say something truthful about human reality), there is still an empty, languid tone to the film that speaks of the dry emotions of the characters in this rather unique world that Kubrick, Spielberg, Winston, and so many others have constructed for us, a world in which characters have to constantly struggle to get back their humanity (yes, even the robots!). All of this is anchored by an extraordinary performance by the boy with six senses, Haley Joel Osment, who provides a Pinocchio pathway back to discovering the self that he never had, with the tears, laughter, and fear of his parents accompanying his pet-oriented abandonment in the backwoods of humanity, left to join a world in which only the adjacent "Blue Fairy" can change him back into a real boy so that he can make his "parents" proud. Yes, folks, there is a lot of Spielberg to this, and I doubt Kubrick would have pulled off anything close to this. In any case, it is also a great example of how a literary source work (by Brian "the brain" Aldiss, in this case) can be used to launch a film project that eventually exists fully as a visual work of its own origin, something which video and film can do that literature cannot--despite the controversies that rage on about which aesthetic medium is better and more substantial. (I know Spielberg is paranoid about recording audio commentaries, but this time it would have been welcomed.) Jude Law, too, actually offers a great performance in the movie, though his character seems to be a bit aloof from the intellectual groundwork provided. Though the public at large probably found this too "slow" and too divergent at the time (I confess that I too thought the robots at the end were aliens instead of robot creatures), this possibility is interesting because Spielberg evidently worked very quickly to bring this off (were Kubrick alive and still working on it, God knows how long we would have had to wait for it). "A. I." proved to be another case of not being the blockbuster that it deserved to be (and the same fate befell Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut", which was also too measured and "head-oriented" for Western movie-going tastes), yet maybe "getting it" is only half the point, since the world on record here is visually magnificent, well-arched, and amazingly paradigmatic. Spielberg seemed to have a need to make the film for Kubrick, and he did it quickly probably to escape some of the emotional pain he may have felt after the loss of Stanley, but even for all of the resigned feeling that I found myself getting after watching the ending, I still find this film to be a classic of film fantasy. Minus the terror, violence, and quick pacing, audiences found it boring, morose, and a bit too "out there." Their loss. A-

I never read any of the reviews before I saw this terrific film, so I didn't know it got mixed reviews. I love the story and its span over the centuries of time. It is brilliant visually and the acting makes it one of the best sci-fi films I have ever seen, and I have a long history, dating back to 1951, of devotion to sci-fi genre. If I had a sci-fi story and script worthy of production, I want Steven Spielberg to direct it. This film, 'AI' is beyond a doubt the saddest film, of any genre, that I've ever experienced; I have a blue-ray copy which I haven't opened in almost two years because I can't bring myself to watch it again.

If you're a Steven Spielberg completest or Stanley Kubrick completest or both then A.I. is a must own...
It's been highly criticized and misunderstood since it was produced - I saw it in the cinema when it was released and thought it beautiful and thought provoking... if I had a criticism at all about this film it is not in the film itself - for it shows us both a beautiful and terrifying future - but in that what it does show us I want more of and we only get what we need. We get David's story.
What I would love to have seen are separate films or even a high quality television anthology series about the future telling exactly what the story of David's father was (William Hurt) or the complete story of Gigolo Joe and Gigolo Jane (Jude Law & Ashley Scott).
A.I. weaves such an interesting tale of the future - humans intermingled with an android/robot race - and the question begs - what are we to do when we as a human race create another species? That's what this film is about, and asks the big questions as all great science-fiction does...
Not unlike Star Trek: The Motion Picture or I Robot... both have similar themes but neither pull it off as brilliantly or as interestingly or as beautifully as Kubrick/Spielberg's Artificial Intelligence does...
As for the ongoing debate about the ending of this film - which I think is perfect, a sort of reverse Jurassic Park with a million times more meaning...

Maybe Steven Spielberg himself said it best:

From Wikipedia: "People pretend to think they know Stanley Kubrick, and think they know me, when most of them don't know either of us," Spielberg told film critic Joe Leydon in 2002. "And what's really funny about that is, all the parts of A.I. that people assume were Stanley's were mine. And all the parts of A.I. that people accuse me of sweetening and softening and sentimentalizing were all Stanley's. The teddy bear was Stanley's. The whole last 20 minutes of the movie was completely Stanley's. The whole first 35, 40 minutes of the film  all the stuff in the house  was word for word, from Stanley's screenplay. This was Stanley's vision."

Like Walt Disney was the king of creating magic for cartoons on the big screen, Steven Spielberg is the king of creating magic for live action. He brought us magical films such as CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND, E.T., and produced the classic comedy, BACK TO THE FUTURE. Then, in 2001, at the height of his creativity, Steven Spielberg brought us ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE. Personally I find it rather offensive how the family is portrayed with the mother as the parent and the father as nothing more than the "mother's husband" as it was on 70's TV shows such as 'Maude' and 'Alice.' But aside from that, A.I. I promise you is yet another Steven Spielberg work of art.

Critics hailed it as "Nonstop magic". And they're so right. There's not one moment in this whole 2 and a half hour epic that won't make your eyes widen. Spielberg just lights up the movie with many creative shots and has a brilliant, remarkable cast, led by the great Haley Joel Osment; who just a year earlier, stole the world's heart in the film PAY IT FORWARD. It's nice to have films that whisk us away into an imaginative world. Something to help us forget out troubles for a moment and just be taken away. ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE does just that. Watch this and you'll be reminded that not all movies are degrading. There's still some that can bring magic into our lives. Steven Spielberg keeps that fact strong.

Spielberg's most misunderstood motion picture gets a startlingly pristine release at last. Blu-Ray is perfectly suited to this film, a film of numerous visual wonders (the integration of models and CGI here is lovely), and rich profundity. In A.I., practically all of the great themes of science fiction are united together in a meditation on the search for meaning and the complexities of creation. Well worth discovering anew, or experiencing for the first time.

I have been an S.F. fan all of my life, and I happen to really appreciate the work of Jude Law as an actor.  The story line of a family in the "near future" who's son is alive, but gravely ill and is being kept in a state of hibernation until there's a cure, "adopt" a robotic boy which is the first to have been made that can have real feelings.  The story is along the lines of a Pinocchio situation; the robotic boy loves his mother a great deal, and the family comes to "accept" him in a warm and charming manner.  Things change though when their real son comes home "cured," and eventually the family chooses to abandon the robotic boy in the "wilderness."  Depending on your nature and who you are, this story can be extremely heart rending, and your emotions can be taken from emotional elation to sadness and even despair.  If your character is of a different "bent" this film will seem schmaltzy, overly emotional and perhaps at times too much of a fairy tale.

Since I gave it 5 stars you have probably figured out I like the film.  Yes, it's a fairy tale.  Yes, it's a modern Pinocchio story.  I grew up with stories like Pinocchio and when I watched this film for the first time, all of those heart-gripping emotions I felt as a kid watching Disney's version of the tale came back and gripped me even stronger, as all of the years that have past in between the two films have added a nostalgic yearning to the feelings.  There are some really good points to how the film was done and who played some of the characters.  Chris Rock was very funny in his part of an "old fashioned robot" with not long left to "live."  Jude Law plays a robot by the name of Gigolo Joe (who knows all the right moves, and aims to please) that accompanies "David," the robotic boy, after he finds his way back out of the wilderness.  Between the two of them many questions are answered as the movie progresses.  The roster of actors in the film is broad, varied and great.

Again, if you don't care for films that tug at the emotions, then look elsewhere, otherwise this is a great film.
